channel.name: Best ways to programmatically check if a transaction failed?

messages.content:
Given a transaction hash, how are you checking if a transaction failed from your programs?

After doing something like:

```ts
sentTxn = await txn.sign([feepayerKey]).send();
```

It looks like there's no functionality to check if a transaction failed from `sentTxn`.

How are you approaching this?

I don't know why I had the idea that `.wait()` would not throw an error if the transaction was rejected and would just wait until confirmed or until it reached the max number of attempts, but this works, thanks!
It used to work like that but was later fixed!
Awesome! :Mina_Mainnet_Toast:
Does anyone have the working code for getting the tx status from the devnet graphql?

I think this sort of query should work: https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blame/64ef49f3c32c35af57001f0e518081b90ee12a88/src/lib/mina/graphql.ts#L274, it's called like this: https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/64ef49f3c32c35af57001f0e518081b90ee12a88/src/lib/mina/fetch.ts#L590

messages.content:
Trying to use this but it is throwing an error with transactions that I can see in the web block explorer:

```ts
import { fetchTransactionStatus } from 'o1js';

const status = await fetchTransactionStatus('5JubhsFCgrPXYrqHHZLG3WQePFG2Tx8Auef5YU2qviHHFrMtcd55', 'https://api.minascan.io/node/devnet/v1/graphql');
console.log(status);
```

Error:
```error
file:///home/chrlyz/wrdhom_server/node_modules/o1js/dist/node/lib/mina/fetch.js:328
        throw Error(error.statusText);
              ^

Error: Invalid transaction provided (((src/common.ml.Read_error Int_code 0)
  "Raised at Bin_prot__Common.raise_read_error in file \"src/common.ml\", line 74, characters 31-60\
 \nCalled from Mina_base__Zkapp_command.T.Stable.V1.With_top_version_tag.bin_read_t_tagged in file \"src/lib/mina_base/zkapp_command.ml\", line 678, characters 6-443\
 \nCalled from Mina_base__Zkapp_command.T.Stable.V1.With_top_version_tag.bin_read_t in file \"src/lib/mina_base/zkapp_command.ml\", line 678, characters 6-443\
 \nCalled from Core_kernel__Binable0.of_bigstring in file \"src/binable0.ml\", line 169, characters 10-41\
 \nCalled from Codable.Make_base64.of_base64 in file \"src/lib/codable/codable.ml\", line 141, characters 15-47\
 \n"))
    at fetchTransactionStatus (file:///home/chrlyz/wrdhom_server/node_modules/o1js/dist/node/lib/mina/fetch.js:328:15)
    at process.processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:95:5)
    at async file:///home/chrlyz/wrdhom_server/build/fetch.js:2:16

Node.js v20.15.0
```
I'll take a look as soon as I can!

It looks like the query expects that the `zkappTransaction` is in a base64 format. I tried to convert the base58 transaction hash to base64 and now instead of the previous `Invalid transaction provided` error,  I'm getting:

With `https://api.minascan.io/node/devnet/v1/graphql`:

```
Error: Bad Gateway
    at fetchTransactionStatus (file:///home/chrlyz/new/node_modules/o1js/dist/node/lib/mina/fetch.js:328:15)
    at process.processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:95:5)
    at async file:///home/chrlyz/new/build/src/readTxn.js:25:16
```

With `https://proxy.devnet.minaexplorer.com/graphql`:

```
Error: request to http://devnet-proxy-coda-1:3085/graphql failed, reason: socket hang up
    at fetchTransactionStatus (file:///home/chrlyz/new/node_modules/o1js/dist/node/lib/mina/fetch.js:328:15)
    at process.processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:95:5)
    at async file:///home/chrlyz/new/build/src/readTxn.js:25:16
```

Not sure if it's because I'm not converting from `Base58` to `Base64` properly or if there's something else going on.

I was wondering if this could be due to some minascan/minaexplorer configuration 🤔 
@Ducca | Staketab @garethtdavies

Any ideas? I also tried to store the `pendingTransaction` with type `Mina.PendingTransaction` in a JSON, to be able to load it and use the `wait` method later, but it seems like this doesn't work, since there's no `PendingTransaction.fromJSON` available to recover this easily from a JSON, and ideally I would like to use `fetchTransactionStatus` or something similar, which is the most straightforward and clean way
Please note that you should handle the case when the tx is replaced in your code, as no info will be returned for replaced tx.

Neat, `checkZkappTransaction` worked, thanks!

What do you mean "for mainnet"? `checkZkappTransaction` worked for devnet and mainnet. When would you use blockberry specifically over a graphQL endpoint?
Well, checkZkappTransaction has limitations, you cannot use it for old txs, so I use blockberry on mainnet and checkZkappTransaction on devnet
It is much easier to detect replaced txs with blockberry too
Got it. Also it seems like `checkZkappTransaction` is only for zkApp transactions and it doesn't work for normal transactions, right? Is there an analog for normal transactions?

For simple payments I use the following code
https://github.com/zkcloudworker/zkcloudworker-aws/blob/main/src/mina/payments.ts
And maybe checkZkappTransaction will work for simple payments too, as it simply calls graphql, never tried. Btw, tx.wait() use it under the hood

I tried to use `checkZkappTransaction` for normal transactions and although it doesn't throw any errors, it looks like it always returns `success: false` even if the payment was succesful.

Yeah, I noticed that about `wait`. Although I still wonder why `fetchTransactionStatus` doesn't work 🤔
Anyways, thanks again, man :Mina_Mainnet_Toast:

I guess that fetchTransactionStatus is sending the graphql query for the tx, and something is broken in the o1js or graphql endpoint for this request. checkZkappTransaction actually looks at the last blocks (you can put the number of blocks as a parameter) and searches there, so those two functions use different graphql queries under the hood.
If you have a simple code example where fetchTransactionStatus does not work, it would be great to raise an issue in o1js github with this reproducible example.
And btw, do you put archive node config when trying to use fetchTransactionStatus?
Yeah, I suspect the same, since it seems to be no intersection between the `fetchTransactionStatus` and `checkZkappTransaction` graphQL queries
I put an example earlier in this question
No, I've been using regular endpoints, but with recent transactions, so their age isn't a factor
